doc.str: In a first treatment step part of at least one difficulty biodegradable or non-biodegradable organic compound is oxidized in polluted water by bringing said polluted water into contact with an ozone containing gas. The effluent is subsequently diluted with an aqueous liquid before a second treatment with ozone is carried out. If the concentration of the organic compound is still not sufficiently low, the treated effluent is diluted again and subjected to a further treatment with ozone. It was found that a more effective ozone treatment was obtained by the dilution or dilutions and that in particular no pH control was needed, so that no formation of additional salts occurred.

Walter Den et al., "Treatment of Organic Wastewater Discharged From Semiconductor Manufacturing Process by Ultraviolet/Hydrogen Peroxide and Biodegradation", IEEE Transactions on Semiconductor Manufacturing, vol. 15, No. 4, pp. 540-551 (Nov. 2002). cited by examiner . | Karel Stopka, "Experiences During 25 Years of Ozonation For Different Industrial Applications", Proceedings of the Annual PAG Conference, pp. 230-231,1997, Presented at IOA/PAG Conference, Lake Tahoe, Nevada, Aug. 18,1997. cited by examiner . | Masten, S. J. et al; "The Use of Ozonation to Degrate Organic Contaminants in Wastewaters Advances in Water Treatment Technologies", Environmental Science and Technology, American Chemical Society, Easton, PA US, vol. 28, No. 4, Apr. 1, 1994, pp. 180A-185A. cited by other . | Camel V. et al, "The Use of Ozone and Associated Oxidation Processes in Drinking Water Treatment", Water Research, Elsevier Science Publishers, Amsterdam, NL, vol. 32, No. 11, Nov. 1, 1998, pp. 3208-3222. cited by other. | Patent Abstracts of Japan, vol. 0040, No. 98 (C-018), Jul. 15, 1980. cited by other .
